agentic-crew

agentic-crew API Reference

Core Module

agentic-crew: Framework-agnostic AI crew orchestration.

Declare crews once, run on CrewAI, LangGraph, or Strands.

Usage:

from agentic_crew.core.decomposer import run_crew_auto, get_runner, detect_framework from agentic_crew.core.discovery import discover_packages, get_crew_config from agentic_crew.core.manager import ManagerAgent

# Auto-detect framework and run a crew packages = discover_packages() config = get_crew_config(packages[“my-package”], “my_crew”) result = run_crew_auto(config, inputs={“task”: “…”})

# Or get a specific runner runner = get_runner(“crewai”) # or “langgraph”, “strands” crew = runner.build_crew(config) result = runner.run(crew, inputs)

# Or use a hierarchical manager agent class MyManager(ManagerAgent):

def __init__(self):
super().__init__(crews={

“design”: “design_crew”, “implementation”: “impl_crew”

})

async def execute_workflow(self, task):

design = await self.delegate_async(“design”, task) return await self.delegate_async(“implementation”, design)

agentic_crew.detect_framework(preferred=None)[source]

Detect the best available AI framework.

Parameters:

preferred (str | None) – Optional preferred framework. If available, use it.

Return type:

str

Returns:

Name of the best available framework.

Raises:

RuntimeError – If no frameworks are installed.

agentic_crew.get_available_frameworks()[source]

Get list of all available frameworks.

Return type:

list[str]

Returns:

List of framework names that are installed.

agentic_crew.is_framework_available(framework)[source]

Check if a framework is installed and importable.

Parameters:

framework (str) – Framework name (crewai, langgraph, strands)

Return type:

bool

Returns:

True if framework is available

agentic_crew.get_runner(framework=None)[source]

Get a runner for the specified or auto-detected framework.

Parameters:

framework (str | None) – Framework name or None for auto-detect.

Return type:

BaseRunner

Returns:

Runner instance for the framework.

Raises:

  • RuntimeError – If framework not available.

  • ValueError – If unknown framework specified.

agentic_crew.decompose_crew(crew_config, framework=None)[source]

Decompose a crew configuration to a framework-specific crew.

This is the core function that converts a framework-agnostic crew definition into a runnable crew for the target framework.

Parameters:

  • crew_config (dict[str, Any]) – Crew configuration from loader.

  • framework (str | None) – Target framework or None for auto-detect. If crew_config has required_framework, that takes precedence.

Return type:

Any

Returns:

Framework-specific crew object ready to run.

Raises:

RuntimeError – If required framework is not available.

agentic_crew.run_crew_auto(crew_config, inputs=None, framework=None)[source]

Run a crew using the best available framework.

Parameters:

  • crew_config (dict[str, Any]) – Crew configuration from loader.

  • inputs (dict[str, Any] | None) – Optional inputs for the crew.

  • framework (str | None) – Optional framework override. If crew_config has required_framework (from .crewai/.strands/.langgraph dir), that takes precedence.

Return type:

str

Returns:

Crew output as string.

Raises:

  • RuntimeError – If required framework is not available.

  • ValueError – If requested framework conflicts with required framework.

agentic_crew.discover_packages(workspace_root=None, framework=None)[source]

Discover all packages with crew configuration directories.

Parameters:

  • workspace_root (Path | None) – Root of the workspace. If None, auto-detected.

  • framework (str | None) – Optional framework to filter by (crewai, langgraph, strands). If None, returns first found directory per package.

Return type:

dict[str, Path]

Returns:

Dict mapping package name to its config directory path.

agentic_crew.discover_all_framework_configs(workspace_root=None)[source]

Discover all framework-specific config directories for all packages.

This finds ALL framework directories, not just the first one per package.

Parameters:

workspace_root (Path | None) – Root of the workspace. If None, auto-detected.

Return type:

dict[str, dict[str | None, Path]]

Returns:

Dict mapping package name to dict of framework -> config_dir. Example: {“otterfall”: {“crewai”: Path(…), “strands”: Path(…)}} Framework can be None for framework-agnostic .crew/ directories.

agentic_crew.get_crew_config(config_dir, crew_name)[source]

Load a specific crew’s configuration.

Parameters:

  • config_dir (Path) – Path to the config directory (.crewai/, .strands/, .langgraph/).

  • crew_name (str) – Name of the crew to load.

Return type:

dict

Returns:

Dict with agents, tasks, knowledge_paths, and required_framework. The required_framework field indicates which framework MUST be used if the config is in a framework-specific directory.

Raises:

ValueError – If crew not found in manifest.

agentic_crew.list_crews(package_name=None, framework=None)[source]

List all available crews, optionally filtered by package or framework.

Parameters:

  • package_name (str | None) – If provided, only list crews for this package.

  • framework (str | None) – If provided, only list crews that can run on this framework.

Return type:

dict[str, list[dict]]

Returns:

Dict mapping package name to list of crew info dicts. Each crew dict includes: - name: Crew name - description: Crew description - required_framework: Framework required (if in framework-specific dir)

class agentic_crew.ManagerAgent[source]

Bases: object

Base class for hierarchical manager agents.

A manager agent orchestrates multiple specialized crews to accomplish complex tasks that require coordination between different domains or phases.

crews

Dict mapping crew role names to crew names in packages.

package_name

Optional package name if all crews are in one package.

workspace_root

Optional workspace root for crew discovery.

__init__(crews, package_name=None, workspace_root=None)[source]

Initialize the manager agent.

Parameters:

  • crews (dict[str, str]) – Dict mapping role names to crew names (e.g., {“design”: “game_design”}).

  • package_name (str | None) – Optional package name if all crews are in the same package.

  • workspace_root (Path | None) – Optional workspace root for discovering packages.

checkpoint(message, result, auto_approve=False)[source]

Create a human-in-the-loop checkpoint.

Parameters:

  • message (str) – Message to display to the human reviewer.

  • result (Any) – Current result to review.

  • auto_approve (bool) – If True, automatically approve without waiting.

Return type:

tuple[bool, Any]

Returns:

Tuple of (approved, result). If not approved, result may be modified.

Note

In this base implementation, checkpoints are logged but auto-approved. Subclasses can override to implement actual HITL workflows.

delegate(crew_role, inputs, framework=None)[source]

Delegate a task to a specific crew synchronously.

Parameters:

  • crew_role (str) – Role name from the crews dict (e.g., “design”).

  • inputs (dict[str, Any] | str) – Input dict or string to pass to the crew.

  • framework (str | None) – Optional framework override.

Return type:

str

Returns:

Crew output as a string.

Raises:

ValueError – If crew_role not found in crews mapping.

async delegate_async(crew_role, inputs, framework=None)[source]

Delegate a task to a specific crew asynchronously.

This runs the crew in a thread pool to avoid blocking the event loop.

Parameters:

  • crew_role (str) – Role name from the crews dict (e.g., “design”).

  • inputs (dict[str, Any] | str) – Input dict or string to pass to the crew.

  • framework (str | None) – Optional framework override.

Return type:

str

Returns:

Crew output as a string.

async delegate_parallel(delegations, framework=None)[source]

Delegate tasks to multiple crews in parallel.

Parameters:

  • delegations (list[tuple[str, dict[str, Any] | str]]) – List of (crew_role, inputs) tuples.

  • framework (str | None) – Optional framework override for all crews.

Return type:

list[str]

Returns:

List of crew outputs in the same order as delegations.

Example

```python results = await manager.delegate_parallel([

(“design”, “Create game concept”), (“assets”, “Generate placeholder assets”),

]) design_result, assets_result = results ```

delegate_sequential(delegations, framework=None)[source]

Delegate tasks to multiple crews sequentially.

Parameters:

  • delegations (list[tuple[str, dict[str, Any] | str]]) – List of (crew_role, inputs) tuples.

  • framework (str | None) – Optional framework override for all crews.

Return type:

list[str]

Returns:

List of crew outputs in the same order as delegations.

Example

```python results = manager.delegate_sequential([

(“design”, “Create game concept”), (“implementation”, “Implement the design”), (“qa”, “Test the implementation”),

])

async execute_workflow(task, **kwargs)[source]

Execute the manager’s workflow.

This is the main entry point for the manager agent. Subclasses should override this method to implement their specific orchestration logic.

Parameters:

  • task (str) – The main task to accomplish.

  • **kwargs (Any) – Additional keyword arguments.

Return type:

str

Returns:

Final result as a string.

Raises:

NotImplementedError – If not overridden by subclass.

Runners

Base Runner

Base runner interface for framework-specific implementations.

All runners must implement this interface to ensure consistent behavior across CrewAI, LangGraph, and Strands.

## Runner Implementation Guide

To create a new runner for a framework:

  1. Subclass BaseRunner: ```python from agentic_crew.runners.base import BaseRunner

    class MyFrameworkRunner(BaseRunner):

    framework_name = “myframework”

    ```

  2. Implement required methods: - build_crew() - Convert universal config to framework crew - run() - Execute the crew and return string output - build_agent() - Create framework-specific agent - build_task() - Create framework-specific task

  3. Register in decomposer (core/decomposer.py): - Add to FRAMEWORK_PRIORITY - Add case to get_runner()

  4. Add optional dependency (pyproject.toml): `toml [project.optional-dependencies] myframework = ["myframework-package>=1.0"] `

## Example Runner

```python class SimpleRunner(BaseRunner):

framework_name = “simple”

def __init__(self):
try:

import simple_framework

except ImportError as e:

raise RuntimeError(“simple_framework not installed”) from e

def build_crew(self, crew_config):

# Use dict to allow lookup by agent name agents = {

name: self.build_agent(cfg) for name, cfg in crew_config.get(“agents”, {}).items()

}

tasks = [] for task_name, task_cfg in crew_config.get(“tasks”, {}).items():

agent_name = task_cfg.get(“agent”) agent = agents[agent_name] tasks.append(self.build_task(task_cfg, agent))

return {“agents”: list(agents.values()), “tasks”: tasks}

def run(self, crew, inputs):

# Execute and return string return “Result from simple framework”

def build_agent(self, agent_config, tools=None):

return {“role”: agent_config[“role”], “tools”: tools or []}

def build_task(self, task_config, agent):

return {“description”: task_config[“description”], “agent”: agent}

```

class agentic_crew.runners.base.BaseRunner[source]

Bases: ABC

Abstract base class for framework runners.

Each framework runner converts agentic-crew’s universal crew format into framework-specific objects and executes them.

framework_name

String identifier for this framework (e.g., “crewai”, “langgraph”, “strands”). Used for logging and framework selection.

Example

Basic runner usage with auto-detection:

```python from agentic_crew.core.decomposer import get_runner

# Auto-detect best available framework runner = get_runner()

crew_config = {

“name”: “research_crew”, “agents”: {

“researcher”: {

“role”: “Senior Researcher”, “goal”: “Find comprehensive information”, “backstory”: “Expert researcher with years of experience”

}

}, “tasks”: {

“research_task”: {

“description”: “Research the topic thoroughly”, “expected_output”: “Detailed research report”, “agent”: “researcher”

}

}

}

# Build and run in one step result = runner.build_and_run(crew_config, {“topic”: “AI safety”}) print(result) ```

framework_name: str = 'base'
abstractmethod build_crew(crew_config)[source]

Build a framework-specific crew from configuration.

This is the main method that converts agentic-crew’s universal YAML-based crew configuration into the framework’s native objects.

Parameters:

crew_config (dict[str, Any]) –

Universal crew configuration dict containing: - name (str): Crew name for identification - description (str): What the crew does - agents (dict): Dict mapping agent names to agent configs.

Each agent config has:

  • role (str): Agent’s role/title

  • goal (str): What the agent aims to achieve

  • backstory (str): Agent’s background/expertise

  • tools (list[str], optional): Tool names to enable

  • llm (str, optional): Model override

  • allow_delegation (bool, optional): Can delegate to others

  • tasks (dict): Dict mapping task names to task configs. Each task config has:

    • description (str): What to do

    • expected_output (str): What output looks like

    • agent (str): Name of agent to execute this task

    • context (list[str], optional): Names of prior tasks

  • knowledge_paths (list[Path], optional): Directories with knowledge files (.md, .txt, etc.)

  • process (str, optional): “sequential” or “hierarchical”

  • required_framework (str, optional): Enforced framework

Returns:

  • CrewAI: crewai.Crew

  • LangGraph: Compiled StateGraph

  • Strands: strands.Agent

Return type:

Framework-specific crew object. Type varies by framework

Raises:

  • ValueError – If configuration is invalid (e.g., unknown agent referenced in task).

  • RuntimeError – If framework is not available.

Example

```python runner = CrewAIRunner() crew = runner.build_crew({

“name”: “writer_crew”, “agents”: {

“writer”: {

“role”: “Technical Writer”, “goal”: “Create clear documentation”, “backstory”: “10 years writing experience”

}

}, “tasks”: {

“write_docs”: {

“description”: “Write API documentation for {topic}”, “expected_output”: “Markdown documentation file”, “agent”: “writer”

}

}

})

abstractmethod run(crew, inputs)[source]

Execute the crew with inputs.

Runs the previously built crew with the given inputs. This method handles the framework-specific execution and normalizes the output to a string.

Parameters:

  • crew (Any) – Framework-specific crew object from build_crew(). Type depends on framework: - CrewAI: crewai.Crew instance - LangGraph: Compiled StateGraph - Strands: strands.Agent instance

  • inputs (dict[str, Any]) – Input dict to pass to the crew. Keys are typically variable names used in task descriptions (e.g., {topic} in description becomes inputs[“topic”]).

Return type:

str

Returns:

Crew output as a string. For complex outputs, the raw text is returned; parsing is left to the caller.

Raises:

RuntimeError – If crew execution fails.

Example

```python # CrewAI runner example result = runner.run(crew, {“topic”: “machine learning”}) print(result) # “## Machine Learning Reportnn…”

# LangGraph runner example result = runner.run(graph, {“input”: “analyze this code”}) ```

build_and_run(crew_config, inputs=None)[source]

Convenience method to build and run in one step.

Parameters:

  • crew_config (dict[str, Any]) – Crew configuration.

  • inputs (dict[str, Any] | None) – Optional inputs for the crew.

Return type:

str

Returns:

Crew output as string.

abstractmethod build_agent(agent_config, tools=None)[source]

Build a framework-specific agent.

Creates a single agent from the universal configuration. Called by build_crew() for each agent in the crew.

Parameters:

  • agent_config (dict[str, Any]) – Agent configuration dict containing: - role (str): Agent’s role/title (e.g., “Senior Researcher”) - goal (str): What the agent aims to achieve - backstory (str): Agent’s background and expertise - llm (str, optional): Model name to override default - allow_delegation (bool, optional): Can delegate tasks - verbose (bool, optional): Enable verbose output

  • tools (list | None) – Optional list of tool instances to give the agent. Tools should already be resolved/instantiated.

Returns:

  • CrewAI: crewai.Agent

  • LangGraph: Compiled ReAct agent graph

  • Strands: strands.Agent

Return type:

Framework-specific agent object

Example

```python # CrewAI agent = runner.build_agent({

“role”: “Data Analyst”, “goal”: “Analyze data and provide insights”, “backstory”: “Expert in statistical analysis”

}, tools=[search_tool, calculator_tool]) ```

abstractmethod build_task(task_config, agent)[source]

Build a framework-specific task.

Creates a single task from the universal configuration. Called by build_crew() for each task in the crew.

Note: Some frameworks (like CrewAI) support additional parameters beyond the base signature. Subclasses may extend this method with optional parameters like context for task dependencies.

Parameters:

  • task_config (dict[str, Any]) –

    Task configuration dict containing: - description (str): What the task should accomplish.

    Can include {placeholders} for runtime inputs.

    • expected_output (str): Description of expected output format

    • async_execution (bool, optional): Run asynchronously

    • human_input (bool, optional): Request human feedback

  • agent (Any) – Framework-specific agent to assign to this task. Must be the return value from build_agent().

Returns:

  • CrewAI: crewai.Task

  • LangGraph: dict (tasks are stored as config)

  • Strands: dict (tasks are stored as config)

Return type:

Framework-specific task object

Example

```python # Basic task task = runner.build_task({

“description”: “Research {topic} thoroughly”, “expected_output”: “Comprehensive research report”

}, agent=researcher_agent)

# CrewAI with context (extended signature) task = crewai_runner.build_task(

task_config, agent, context=[prior_research_task] # CrewAI-specific

)

get_llm(model=None)[source]

Get the LLM for this framework.

Retrieves or creates an LLM instance. The default implementation uses agentic-crew’s shared LLM configuration. Subclasses may override for framework-specific LLM handling.

Parameters:

model (str | None) – Optional model name override. If None, uses DEFAULT_MODEL from agentic_crew.config.llm (usually claude-sonnet-4-20250514).

Return type:

Any

Returns:

Framework-specific LLM object, or None if the LLM module is not available (framework may have its own default).

  • CrewAI: LiteLLM-compatible LLM

  • LangGraph: langchain ChatModel

  • Strands: Uses model_id directly

Example

```python # Use default model llm = runner.get_llm()

# Use specific model llm = runner.get_llm(“claude-haiku-4-5-20251001”)

# In LangGraphRunner (overridden) llm = runner.get_llm(“claude-sonnet-4-20250514”) # Returns ChatAnthropic ```

CrewAI Runner

CrewAI runner implementation.

This is the default and most full-featured runner. CrewAI provides: - Hierarchical and sequential processes - Memory and planning - Knowledge sources - Tool integration - Delegation between agents

LangGraph Runner

LangGraph runner implementation.

LangGraph excels at: - Complex conditional flows - State management - Cycles and loops - Integration with LangChain ecosystem

build_task(task_config, agent)[source]

Build a task representation for LangGraph.

In LangGraph, tasks are typically represented as graph nodes or prompts to agents. Returns a dict for now.

Parameters:

  • agent (Any) – Agent for the task.

Return type:

Any

Returns:

Task configuration dict with agent reference.

Strands Runner

AWS Strands runner implementation.

Strands is lightweight and AWS-native, good for: - Simple agent workflows - AWS Bedrock integration - Minimal dependencies - Plain Python function tools

build_task(task_config, agent)[source]

Build a task for Strands.

In Strands, tasks are prompts to the agent. Returns a dict that can be used to construct prompts.

Parameters:

  • task_config (dict[str, Any]) – Task configuration.

  • agent (Any) – Agent for the task.

Return type:

Any

Returns:

Task configuration dict.

Core Components

Decomposer

Framework decomposition - auto-detect and select AI framework.

This module provides the core capability of agentic-crew: declaring crews once and running them on CrewAI, LangGraph, or Strands depending on what’s installed. It also supports single-agent CLI runners for simpler tasks.

Usage:

from agentic_crew.core.decomposer import get_runner, detect_framework

# Auto-detect best framework for multi-agent framework = detect_framework()

# Get runner for that framework runner = get_runner(framework)

# Or let it auto-select runner = get_runner() # Uses best available

# Get single-agent CLI runner from agentic_crew.core.decomposer import get_cli_runner runner = get_cli_runner(“aider”)

bool

agentic_crew.core.decomposer.get_runner(framework=None)[source]

Get a runner for the specified or auto-detected framework.

Parameters:

framework (str | None) – Framework name or None for auto-detect.

Return type:

BaseRunner

Returns:

Runner instance for the framework.

Raises:

  • RuntimeError – If framework not available.

  • ValueError – If unknown framework specified.

agentic_crew.core.decomposer.get_cli_runner(profile, model=None)[source]

Get a single-agent CLI runner for the specified profile.

Parameters:

  • profile (str | dict[str, Any]) – Profile name (e.g., “aider”, “claude-code”, “ollama”) or custom config dict.

  • model (str | None) – Optional model override.

Return type:

SingleAgentRunner

Returns:

LocalCLIRunner instance for the profile.

Raises:

  • ValueError – If profile not found.

  • FileNotFoundError – If profiles file missing.

Examples

# Use built-in profile runner = get_cli_runner(“aider”) result = runner.run(“Add error handling to auth.py”)

# Use with model override runner = get_cli_runner(“ollama”, model=”deepseek-coder”) result = runner.run(“Fix the bug”)

# Use custom config runner = get_cli_runner({

“command”: “my-tool”, “task_flag”: “–task”, “auto_approve”: “–yes”,

})

Return type:

list[str]

Returns:

List of profile names (e.g., [“aider”, “claude-code”, “ollama”]).

agentic_crew.core.decomposer.decompose_crew(crew_config, framework=None)[source]

Decompose a crew configuration to a framework-specific crew.

This is the core function that converts a framework-agnostic crew definition into a runnable crew for the target framework.

Parameters:

  • crew_config (dict[str, Any]) – Crew configuration from loader.

  • framework (str | None) – Target framework or None for auto-detect. If crew_config has required_framework, that takes precedence.

Return type:

Any

Returns:

Framework-specific crew object ready to run.

Raises:

RuntimeError – If required framework is not available.

agentic_crew.core.decomposer.run_crew_auto(crew_config, inputs=None, framework=None)[source]

Run a crew using the best available framework.

Parameters:

  • crew_config (dict[str, Any]) – Crew configuration from loader.

  • inputs (dict[str, Any] | None) – Optional inputs for the crew.

  • framework (str | None) – Optional framework override. If crew_config has required_framework (from .crewai/.strands/.langgraph dir), that takes precedence.

Return type:

str

Returns:

Crew output as string.

Raises:

  • RuntimeError – If required framework is not available.

  • ValueError – If requested framework conflicts with required framework.

Loader

Loader module - creates CrewAI Crew objects from YAML configurations.

Note: This module imports CrewAI lazily to allow the core package to be installed without requiring CrewAI. For framework-agnostic usage, prefer using the decomposer module with runners instead.

list

Returns:

List of TextFileKnowledgeSource objects.

Raises:

ImportError – If crewai is not installed.

Return type:

Raises:

ImportError – If crewai is not installed.

Discovery

Discovery module - finds packages with crew configuration directories.

Supports framework-specific configuration directories: - .crewai/ - CrewAI-specific configurations (default) - .langgraph/ - LangGraph-specific configurations - .strands/ - Strands-specific configurations

The discovery order matches framework priority for auto-detection.

agentic_crew.core.discovery.get_workspace_root()[source]

Get the workspace root directory.

Walks up from the current file to find the root (where pyproject.toml is).

Return type:

Path

agentic_crew.core.discovery.discover_packages(workspace_root=None, framework=None)[source]

Discover all packages with crew configuration directories.

Parameters:

  • workspace_root (Path | None) – Root of the workspace. If None, auto-detected.

  • framework (str | None) – Optional framework to filter by (crewai, langgraph, strands). If None, returns first found directory per package.

Return type:

dict[str, Path]

Returns:

Dict mapping package name to its config directory path.

agentic_crew.core.discovery.discover_all_framework_configs(workspace_root=None)[source]

Discover all framework-specific config directories for all packages.

This finds ALL framework directories, not just the first one per package.

Parameters:

workspace_root (Path | None) – Root of the workspace. If None, auto-detected.

Return type:

dict[str, dict[str | None, Path]]

Returns:

Dict mapping package name to dict of framework -> config_dir. Example: {“otterfall”: {“crewai”: Path(…), “strands”: Path(…)}} Framework can be None for framework-agnostic .crew/ directories.

agentic_crew.core.discovery.get_crew_config(config_dir, crew_name)[source]

Load a specific crew’s configuration.

Parameters:

  • config_dir (Path) – Path to the config directory (.crewai/, .strands/, .langgraph/).

  • crew_name (str) – Name of the crew to load.

Return type:

dict

Returns:

Dict with agents, tasks, knowledge_paths, and required_framework. The required_framework field indicates which framework MUST be used if the config is in a framework-specific directory.

Raises:

ValueError – If crew not found in manifest.

agentic_crew.core.discovery.list_crews(package_name=None, framework=None)[source]

List all available crews, optionally filtered by package or framework.

Parameters:

  • package_name (str | None) – If provided, only list crews for this package.

  • framework (str | None) – If provided, only list crews that can run on this framework.

Return type:

dict[str, list[dict]]

Returns:

Dict mapping package name to list of crew info dicts. Each crew dict includes: - name: Crew name - description: Crew description - required_framework: Framework required (if in framework-specific dir)

Configuration

LLM Configuration

LLM Configuration for CrewAI agents.

Uses Anthropic Claude directly via ANTHROPIC_API_KEY. Falls back to OpenRouter if OPENROUTER_API_KEY is set.

class agentic_crew.config.llm.LLMProvider[source]

Bases: Enum

Available LLM providers.

ANTHROPIC = 'anthropic'
OPENROUTER = 'openrouter'

Bases: object

Configuration for specific LLM use cases.

model: str
temperature: float

agentic_crew.config.llm.get_llm(model='claude-haiku-4-5-20251001', temperature=0.7, provider=None)[source]

Get configured LLM instance for CrewAI agents.

Parameters:

  • model (str) – Model identifier. Defaults to claude-haiku-4-5-20251001 (DEFAULT_MODEL)

  • temperature (float) – Sampling temperature (0.0-1.0). Lower = more focused, higher = more creative.

  • provider (LLMProvider | None) – Force specific provider (ANTHROPIC or OPENROUTER). If None, auto-detects based on available API keys.

Return type:

LLM | None

Available models:

  • claude-haiku-4-5-20251001 (default - fast, cost-effective)

  • claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929 (best for code and creative)

  • claude-sonnet-4-20250514 (capable general purpose)

  • claude-opus-4-20250514 (most capable)

  • openrouter/auto (fallback via OpenRouter)

Return type:

LLM | None

Returns:

Configured LLM instance, or None if no API key set

Parameters:

  • model (str)

  • temperature (float)

  • provider (LLMProvider | None)

Note

Tries ANTHROPIC_API_KEY first, falls back to OPENROUTER_API_KEY. Returns None if neither is set, allowing CrewAI to use its default.

Example

>>> llm = get_llm()  # Uses Claude Haiku 4.5
>>> llm = get_llm("claude-opus-4-20250514", temperature=0.3)
>>> llm = get_llm(provider=LLMProvider.OPENROUTER)
agentic_crew.config.llm.get_llm_or_raise(model='claude-haiku-4-5-20251001', temperature=0.7, provider=None)[source]

Get configured LLM instance, raising if API key not set.

Use this when you need to ensure an LLM is available.

Parameters:

  • model (str) – Model identifier (see get_llm for options)

  • temperature (float) – Sampling temperature (0.0-1.0)

  • provider (LLMProvider | None) – Force specific provider (optional)

Return type:

LLM

Returns:

Configured LLM instance

Raises:

ValueError – If neither ANTHROPIC_API_KEY nor OPENROUTER_API_KEY is set

agentic_crew.config.llm.get_llm_for_task(task)[source]

Get LLM configured for a specific task type.

Parameters:

task (str) – Task type - one of: ‘reasoning’, ‘creative’, ‘code’, ‘default’

Return type:

LLM | None

Returns:

Configured LLM instance, or None if no API key set

Raises:

ValueError – If task type is unknown

Example

>>> llm = get_llm_for_task('code')  # Low temp, optimized for code
>>> llm = get_llm_for_task('creative')  # High temp, creative output

Tools

File Tools

File manipulation tools for CrewAI agents.

These tools enable agents to read and write code to specific directories in game package codebases (e.g., packages/otterfall).

agentic_crew.tools.file_tools.get_workspace_root(package_name=None)[source]

Get the workspace root directory for the target game code package.

Returns packages/<package_name> as the workspace root, where the game code lives.

Uses marker file search to find workspace root reliably, regardless of where this module is installed or imported from.

Parameters:

package_name (str | None) – Name of the target package. If not provided, uses TARGET_PACKAGE environment variable, or defaults to “otterfall”.

Return type:

Path

Returns:

Path to packages/<package_name> directory.
